articles.headline: Tax Bill Thrown Into Uncertainty as First G.O.P. Senator Comes Out Against It
articles.snippet: Senator Ron Johnson of Wisconsin said he opposed both the House and Senate tax plans as written, posing a new obstacle to Republican leaders eager to overhaul the tax code.
articles.abstract: Senator Ron Johnson of Wisconsin said he opposed both the House and Senate tax plans as written, posing a new obstacle to Republican leaders eager to overhaul the tax code.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Uncertainty gripped the Senate on Wednesday over efforts to pass a sweeping $1.5 trillion tax cut after a Wisconsin Republican became the first senator in his party to declare that he could not vote for the tax bill as written, and other senators expressed serious misgivings over the cost and effect on the middle class.
articles.byline: By Alan Rappeport and Thomas Kaplan

articles.headline: Under Trump, Banking Watchdog Trades Its Bite for a Tamer Stance
articles.snippet: A change in course has made the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency, which oversees the nation’s biggest banks, part of a campaign to roll back regulations.
articles.abstract: A change in course has made the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency, which oversees the nation’s biggest banks, part of a campaign to roll back regulations.
articles.lead_paragraph: After the financial crisis in 2008, the Obama administration turned one of the banking industry’s friendliest regulators into one of its toughest. But that agency is now starting to look like its old self — and becoming a vital player in the Trump administration’s campaign to roll back regulations.
articles.byline: By Ben Protess and Jessica Silver-Greenberg

articles.headline: 4 More Women Accuse Roy Moore of Misconduct
articles.snippet: Accusations of groping and unwanted overtures surfaced as Mr. Moore’s campaign tried to cast doubt on the credibility of one of his accusers.
articles.abstract: Accusations of groping and unwanted overtures surfaced as Mr. Moore’s campaign tried to cast doubt on the credibility of one of his accusers.
articles.lead_paragraph: GADSDEN, Ala. — Alabama’s increasingly bizarre Senate race was convulsed again as four more women came forward on Wednesday to describe encounters with the Republican candidate, Roy S. Moore, and Mr. Moore’s campaign sharply questioned the credibility of another accuser.

articles.headline: With Mugabe’s Era Ending in Zimbabwe, a Warning Echoes in Africa
articles.snippet: Robert Mugabe has led Zimbabwe since 1980, but he underestimated his nation’s anger over his son’s unrestrained spending and his wife’s political ambitions.
articles.abstract: Robert Mugabe has led Zimbabwe since 1980, but he underestimated his nation’s anger over his son’s unrestrained spending and his wife’s political ambitions.
articles.lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG — When Zimbabwe’s generals moved against President Robert Mugabe on Wednesday, their action foreshadowed the potential end of more than just one political career. It echoed across a continent where the notion of the “big man” leader is defined equally by the lure of power in perpetuity and the risk that, one day, the edifice will crumble under the weight of its own decay.
articles.byline: By Norimitsu Onishi and Alan Cowell

articles.headline: Amazon Sellers Brood as States Come Calling for Taxes
articles.snippet: Most third-party sellers on Amazon do not collect sales tax. States, thirsty for the millions of dollars in unpaid revenue, are coming for the money.
articles.abstract: Most third-party sellers on Amazon do not collect sales tax. States, thirsty for the millions of dollars in unpaid revenue, are coming for the money.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Amazon and the tax man are back at it again.

articles.headline: Deception and Ruses Fill the Toolkit of Investigators Used by Weinstein
articles.snippet: Black Cube, hired to ferret out information on a Weinstein accuser, used an elaborate ruse involving a fake job interview in another case.
articles.abstract: Black Cube, hired to ferret out information on a Weinstein accuser, used an elaborate ruse involving a fake job interview in another case.
articles.lead_paragraph: Earlier this month, a former hedge fund employee was flown from Hong Kong to London for a job interview. Around the same time, a current employee of the same Toronto hedge fund was also flown to London for interviews. The company courting them was fake. Its website was fake. There were no jobs to be had, and the woman who set up the interviews was not a recruiter but an agent working for an Israeli private investigative firm.
articles.byline: By Matthew Goldstein and William K. Rashbaum

articles.headline: Meredith Bid for Time Inc. Said to Be Backed by Koch Brothers
articles.snippet: The billionaire Koch brothers are said to have tentatively agreed to support the publisher Meredith’s offer with an equity injection of more than $500 million.
articles.abstract: The billionaire Koch brothers are said to have tentatively agreed to support the publisher Meredith’s offer with an equity injection of more than $500 million.
articles.lead_paragraph: Time Inc. is said to be in talks to sell itself to the Meredith Corporation, in a deal backed by Charles G. and David H. Koch, the billionaire brothers known for supporting conservative causes.
articles.byline: By Sydney Ember and Andrew Ross Sorkin

articles.headline: Jet Pilot Might Not Seem Like a ‘Gig,’ but at Ryanair, It Is
articles.snippet: The biggest European budget airline employs many of its pilots as contract workers — many of whom are pushing back after a recent flight cancellation episode erupted into a clash.
articles.abstract: The biggest European budget airline employs many of its pilots as contract workers — many of whom are pushing back after a recent flight cancellation episode erupted into a clash.
articles.lead_paragraph: At a recent shareholders’ meeting in Dublin, Michael O’Leary, the chief executive of Ryanair, slumped into a leather chair and issued a mea culpa. Under his watch, Europe’s biggest low-cost airline had bungled its fall vacation schedule for pilots. Over 2,000 flights would have to be canceled.
articles.byline: By Liz Alderman and Amie Tsang

articles.headline: I.R.S. Starts to Enforce Health Law’s Rule That Employers Offer Insurance
articles.snippet: Thousands of businesses, many of them small or midsize, will soon get a letter saying they owe penalties because they failed to offer qualifying insurance.
articles.abstract: Thousands of businesses, many of them small or midsize, will soon get a letter saying they owe penalties because they failed to offer qualifying insurance.
articles.lead_paragraph: As Republicans and the Trump administration continue trying to chip away at the Affordable Care Act, the Internal Revenue Service has begun, for the first time, to enforce one of the law’s most polarizing provisions: the employer mandate.

articles.headline: Bill Signals Top Tax Priority of G.O.P. Is to Help Corporations
articles.snippet: There are tough choices at the heart of the Republican tax bills speeding through Congress, and they make clear the party values deep and lasting tax cuts for corporations above all else.
articles.abstract: There are tough choices at the heart of the Republican tax bills speeding through Congress, and they make clear the party values deep and lasting tax cuts for corporations above all else.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — There are tough choices at the heart of the Republican tax bills speeding through Congress, and they make clear what the party values most in economic policy right now: deep and lasting tax cuts for corporations.

articles.headline: House Passes Tax Bill, as Does Senate Panel
articles.snippet: The tax overhaul still faces significant obstacles, as Republicans seek to align the House legislation with a version that is under consideration in the Senate.
articles.abstract: The tax overhaul still faces significant obstacles, as Republicans seek to align the House legislation with a version that is under consideration in the Senate.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With 227 Republican votes, the House passed the most sweeping tax overhaul in three decades on Thursday, taking a significant leap forward as lawmakers seek to enact $1.5 trillion in tax cuts for businesses and individuals and deliver the first major legislative achievement of President Trump’s tenure.
articles.byline: By Thomas Kaplan and Alan Rappeport

articles.headline: A Star on Washington’s Ice With a No. 1 Fan at the Kremlin
articles.snippet: Alexander Ovechkin’s play for the Capitals has made him a cherished import, but his ties to Russia and President Vladimir V. Putin have raised eyebrows.
articles.abstract: Alexander Ovechkin’s play for the Capitals has made him a cherished import, but his ties to Russia and President Vladimir V. Putin have raised eyebrows.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The son of Moscow makes his living in Washington, cheered nightly by locals who think little of his country.
